msg: Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
Simple bug fix for a regression in styles validation with -compatibility-version=3 (the compiler was complaining about class selectors in non-top level <Style> declarations).
Also adding a small bridge class to link mxmlc's path resolver with fxgutils resource resolver.
QE: Yes, a quick check of SDK-20357 would be great.
SDK-20357 - When you compile an application with with -compatibility-version=3, class selectors in mxml components won't work.
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
Integrating latest fxgutils which also fixes SDK-20777.

Restoring FXG TextGraphic attribute validation and overriding createGraphicContext() so that transform attributes are left to programmatic generation so that we don't duplicate them between SWF primitives and ActionScript.

Also adding an advanced command line configuration switch --qualified-type-selectors=true or false to ease migration of legacy applications to Flex 4 so that CSS type selectors can be left unqualified for the case where an application only makes use of halo components. If -compatibility-version=3, this setting will always be false, and type selectors are unqualified.
QE: Yes, please confirm fix to and add a small test case of an MXML 2006 based application that makes use of unqualified type selectors.

Doc: For the migration guide, we may want to document the advanced --qualified-type-selectors switch for folks who do not want to run with -compatibility-version=3 but cannot up all of their type selectors.
SDK-20777 - EmptyStackException when <private> is indirectly nested in <private>
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
API changes from PARB review of Advanced CSS additions.
- Remove CSSSelectorKind enum as it is not needed.
- Update CSSStyleDeclaration constructor to accept either a CSSSelector or legacy String selector.
- Update CSSConditionKind enum to use Strings
- Revert concept of StyleManager.addCSSStyleDeclaration() so that we continue to use the Flex 3 restriction of one CSSStyleDeclaration per unique selector String.
- Minor renames for lower level APIs such as IAdvancedStyleClient's isPseudoSelectorMatch() -> matchesCSSState(), and isTypeSelectorMatch)() -> matchesCSSType()
- Update ASDoc comment version info for APIs that were really added in Gumbo
- Add compiler warning for unqualified type selectors (e.g. when a type selector probably needs a namespace prefix).
- Add compiler warning for unresolved qualified type selector (e.g. when a type is probably missing from a manifest).
QE: I have an update for the mustella tests of programmatic creation of CSSStyleDeclaration
Doc: Yes, if we can do an ASDoc review of CSS classes in the framework it would be much appreciated.
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository

Fixing compatibility-version=3 mode as it seems there are two ways in StylesContainer that look for dependencies against type selectors, one path is for developer specified styles, the other is for default styles.
Setting compatibility mode to 3 for checkinapp.
Also removing minor debug output left in build.xml for component smokes ant target.
QE: This too will help if you're relying on compatibility mode to compile MXML 2006 apps after the rename.
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
1st pass of rename according to the spec http://opensource.adobe.com/wiki/display/flexsdk/Dropping+the+Fx+Prefix

Flex now requires CSS Style declarations to declare @namespace rules and disambiguate between halo and spark components using CSS 3 namespace prefixes on type selectors. At compile time, this namespace information will be used to map type names to qualified ActionScript class names. At runtime, type selectors are matched on qualified ActionScript class name (for example mx.controls.Button rather than just Button). Flex 3 applications must be compiled with -compatibility-version=3.0.0 to get unqualified CSS type selector behavior.
QE: Yes, this build may help in updating test cases to use the new namespaces and class names.
